intro: Uebelinia kigesiensis subsp. ragazziana, commonly known as the East African spurge, is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family. It is a shrub or small tree native to eastern Africa, characterized by its rough, bark-like stems and alternate, ovate leaves. The plant produces small, clustered yellow flowers, followed by distinctive three-lobed seed capsules. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forest margins and riverine habitats. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
